This was ofc my personal answer given some of my own experiences within tech.

How might you approach answering this question?

What other advice would you give?

1111639890683461633.text: All of this (and more) matters and can play into the scenarios in a multitude of ways when working on teams in development.

1111639887608987655.text: And context will mean things like 1) what does the team look like now which would inform their perceptions? 2) how are the skillsets already distributed and where might they need others? or 3) why are certain choices made and who can decide to make them?...

1111639884727500800.text: That said, I do think the answers any mindful person should give would be along the lines of “it will be specific to the team and project”. This doesn’t necessarily mean “it depends” relatively, but that THE CONTEXT WILL MATTER.

1111639880608686081.text: Specific types of projects for joining a dev team: at a minimum, the types of projects that really resonate with *you* and help you to share that infectious enthusiasm

1111639877832060934.text: Skill-levels for joining a dev team: comfortable enough to know what you know, and what you don’t know (and be able to communicate it, navigate it, and show initiative for learning, always and more)

1105433760345010176.text: This is an example of visualizing decision-making. Instead of Y/N, a group maps their 1) Preferences 2) Tolerances & 3) Objections to find more decision space w overlap + expanded common ground, adding “I could tolerate” in between “I prefer” vs “I object to/could not tolerate”.pic.twitter.com/MXlxpvi0nW

1105091489909088256.text: Another example had to do with conflict resolution protocols, and utilizing a structure of stewardship circles in a community to aid in resolving inevitable conflicts.

1105091485165330432.text: One had to do with decision-making protocols, and breaking open the previously binary spectrum of “yes/no” in deciding to include more nuance. Also, adding more “tools to the box” beyond consensus, to consent, advice, etc gave us the ability to better listen + coordinate.

1102557564779352067.text:
To be honest I was personally a bit skeptical of the piggy bank image at the start, but then I was glad our team pushed for it since pigs do have a wonderful symbolic history tied to wealth!

The prototype we wanted provoked more questions about notions like friendship + wealth.

1102557557242109952.text: The keychain was laser-cut from Birch wood. We wanted it to be simple, light-hearted, fun + playful. It was super exciting to make the prototype artefact, as this tangible "thingly" thing to be experienced — thank you @gianpangaro for the guidance + intro to this machine wonder!pic.twitter.com/3frwbJ5Q2Q

1102557551563075584.text:
How might we help friends have more + better conversations about money?

Some core questions that provoked our intentions in the prototype had to do w/ reducing the stigma around convos like these + encouraging care for a shared commons, just like friends that "have your back".pic.twitter.com/cH6I26ustH

1102557545296789507.text: How might we help friends help payback other friends? How might we embed a more empathetic approach to lending? How might we share community wealth more fairly as a commons? How might we utilize more shared community wealth to care for personal risk and volatility?pic.twitter.com/HWmgW5TqS1

1102557539944882176.text: How might we help friends share their money without tasking the friendship? How might we augment friendships, and help keep them together? How might we reinforce bonds of mutual support in p2p loaning? How might we humanize things like default?pic.twitter.com/lXtvnIjwV9

1102557534924296192.text: Our HMW (how might we) question-generation really took us into turbo-mode. This part in our exercises was the fuel that lit our fire, and really started turning a lot of the liminal, lingering notions in our discussions into fireworks.pic.twitter.com/28uZYtFMdq

1102557533502349312.text: Brainstorming around our brief, we also realized that there were deep merging phenomena between *gifts*+ loans when it came to friendships and close connections. We saw the potential of the opportunity to shift the first experience to "giving" before asking.pic.twitter.com/htT4uBtEq2

1102557528334962690.text:
Our journeying revealed to us that a lot of about the current widespread ways we might ask friends for loans begins with an "ask", and that there are a lot of under-emphasized interactions of mutual support between friends.

"If I don't pay my friend back, *my friend suffers*."pic.twitter.com/JzYIP3307H

1102557527647105024.text: We went using a burner wallet on a state channel for rapid fast (~2hr) prototyping & chose a keychain+QR for simple contributions thanks to portability. In theory, funds could then be later swept to more secure holding + experimented w/ in models like Venmo-esque cash sweeps.

1102557521255022592.text: We ran out of time to fully integrate the hardware to observe + signal when new funds were added to the wallet, but all contributions were immediately live on @etherscan. We wanted that the pool could also flexibly enjoy lending of diverse assets (eg, ETH/DAI, tokens, etc).pic.twitter.com/Nzr0ZTrjVJ

1102557519644409857.text:
Imagine the experience of getting a little sensory notification of friends+friends making contributions to your shared savings pool 

Transparency + coordination + shared joyful magicpic.twitter.com/brnz87NM6Z

Their compassion + understanding are not lost on me, and I hope to have the opportunity to pay it forward to someone else sometime soon. /23

1102280740241321984.text: We arrived in JFK airport close to 11:00 PM EST, rented a car, and drove overnight to Cambridge, MA to be able to be part of the event the following Saturday morning. /22

1102280738915975169.text:
They implored us to act extremely quickly, since the JFK flight was closing in ~20 minutes — so we did. We arrived at the gate just as they were finishing boarding, because our check-in took extra time since my partner is a Mexican national.
 /21

1102280736789463042.text: The @AirFranceFR team should be aware of and very honored of the actions of their team on Friday night. They were kind, helpful, humane, understanding & empathetic. They could not believe how we were treated, and were very conscious of the impression Paris left on visitors. /20

1102280735187185665.text: When we arrived, the @airfrance personnel at ticketing went out of their way to try to help soothe my visible desperation, stress and anxiety, offering water and just being overall kind human beings. /19

1102280734239268864.text: In the car I was cross-referencing the departures out of Paris, w/ the arrivals into San Francisco, & Boston, trying everything I could think of. The only option to be had was an Air France flight departing for JFK, too soon to be booked via anything but the airport counter. /18

1102280733429850114.text: We quickly decided if there was going to be any chance it was probably out of Charles De Gaulle airport, so after French Bee refused us until the plane left at 17:50, we took a taxi from Orly to @CDG. /17

1102280732603572225.text: We asked the French bee personnel for their names, to help us document the situation; they emphatically refused. My partner had even overheard one of them referring to us with expletives in French. This is all still while I am trying to recover from an attack of anxiety. /16

1102280731831746560.text: We asked the French bee personnel to speak with management; they said there was no one else to speak to. We asked for a customer support number for the company; they gave us a phone # that when we called was unhelpful & seemed to be set-up specifically for this SFO flight. /15

1102280730879639554.text: A woman from Orly tried to help us & helped try to console me. She apologized profusely, and could not get over this episode that was unraveling. Her words were "We do not treat people like this. You do not treat people like this." @Orly_Paris should be aware of her kindness. /14

1102280730066018306.text: I was in a state of complete shock. A company refusing to print out a bar code on a boarding pass for checked-in passengers to board an 11-hr long-haul flight was something I had never in my life even heard of happening. /13

1102280728723759105.text: With tears streaming down my face I even tried anything to get us to Boston Logan, knowing of the sister event in Cambridge. There was nothing getting us even to Boston in time. I was still sobbing at the French bee desk, I could not help it. /12

1102280727876550656.text:
We frantically tried everything we could: searching for any other flights leaving Paris to anywhere close to San Francisco, or to fly to any other stops and then on to San Francisco. Nothing would get us there in time for the event I was attending at 8:30 Saturday morning.
 /11

1102280726937026569.text: We pleaded w/ the @Orly_Paris airport personnel to help. They were *equally appalled* & shocked by the curt, rude & uncaring actions of French Bee. They could not understand why this company was refusing to board people when still visibly & viably possible at the gate. /10

1102280725347340288.text: I sobbed uncontrollably in the airport. I begged the French Bee personnel — we had already been “checked-in” since the day before, and this company practices the dubious, flag-raising tactic of withholding valid boarding passes with “barcodes” until printed out solely by them. /9

1102280722327441409.text: The heavy traffic in Paris meant that we arrived at the airport at 16:34 CEST. Again, this was for a 17:50 PM CEST flight (!), 1 hour and 20 minutes before the flight was to leave. /7

1102280721471864832.text: We were planning to arrive at the airport, like most travelers are recommended to do, around ~2 hours before our departure time, which was scheduled for 17:50 CEST.  The boarding time was 16:40 CEST. /6

1102280719471120384.text: We had rushed back from the city center at 15:35, since the projected time to return was now ~1 hr, double what it had been in the morning when we arrived (~30 mins). Our @taxifyapp driver was so helpful and did his best to get us through the traffic. /5pic.twitter.com/0l9GAIIunL

1102280718351253510.text: In a shock of incredulity and desperation we were denied our boarding passes by the @flyfrenchbee airline at Paris Orly when we arrived at 16:34 CEST. /4

1102280717516660737.text: We booked this flight on my @AmericanExpress even with the long 7+ hour layover in Paris, since we were trying our best to stay on a reasonable budget. We could only stay the weekend in San Francisco, and this event was extremely important to me. /3

1102280716564467713.text: Our next flight to SFO was to depart Paris Orly on #FrenchBee at 17:50 CEST, and arrive in SFO at 8:30PM PST.  We booked this as a package deal via @eDreams_en, and it was two legs operated by these different “low-cost” carriers. /2

1102280715738193920.text: On Friday, March 1 at 5:00AM CEST, I left Turin, Italy with my partner to make the trip to San Francisco for the IDEO event.  We took the 2 hr bus ride to Milan, and boarded our first flight with @vueling to Paris Orly, arriving at 11:00AM CEST. /1
